Article Title: 'Endured what happened to me but my sister ... ': Tej Pratap slams Jaichands for 'insulting' Rohini; Lalu family feud escalates
Article Text:
In a passionate outburst, Tej Pratap Yadav took aim at family members and RJD associates whom he branded as 'betrayers' for disrespecting his sister, Rohini Acharya. This vehement reaction came on the heels of Rohini's retirement from the political arena and ongoing family turmoil.

NEW DELHI: Tej Pratap Yadav on Monday again launched a strong attack on individuals within his family and RJD, accusing them of acting like ‚Äútraitors‚Äù and warning that he would not accept any insult directed at his sister.His remarks come days after RJD chief Lalu Prasad Yadav ‚Äôs daughter Rohini Acharya announced her exit from politics and severed ties with the family, a move followed by three of her sisters reportedly leaving the Patna residence amid the escalating dispute.In a post on X, the Janshakti Tej Pratap wrote: ‚ÄúWe will not tolerate any insult to our sister under any circumstances; the traitors will surely have to pay the price for this misconduct!‚Äù‚ÄúThe abuse that was done to our Rohini di by Jaichand, this incident has shaken my heart to the core. What happened to me, I have endured, but what happened to my sister ‚Äî that insult is absolutely unacceptable under any circumstances. Listen, Jaichand, if you attack the family, the people of Bihar will never forgive you,‚Äù Tej Pratap added in his post.This marks the latest development in months of turmoil within the Yadav family, which saw Tej Pratap himself expelled from both the RJD and the family following a bitter dispute over his personal life.Earlier, on Sunday, following Rohini Acharya‚Äôs announcement, Tej Pratap shared an emotionally charged post on his party‚Äôs Instagram account, warning those he described as ‚Äútraitors‚Äù and appealing directly to his father.‚ÄúYesterday‚Äôs incident has shaken me to the core. What happened to me ‚Äî I endured it. But the insult done to my sister is absolutely unbearable under any circumstances. Listen, traitors‚Äî if you target our family, the people of Bihar will never forgive you. When the emotions of the people are wounded, the dust covering their judgment is blown away,‚Äù he wrote.He also accused them of influencing his brother Tejashwi‚Äôs political judgment.‚ÄúThese few faces have even clouded Tejashwi‚Äôs judgment. The consequences of this injustice will be extremely grave. Time‚Äôs reckoning is harsh,‚Äù he added.Also read: Nitish Kumar resigns as Bihar CM: Cabinet backs assembly dissolution; oath ceremony on Nov 20 The JJP chief also urged Lalu Prasad Yadav to intervene: ‚ÄúFather, give just one signal‚Ä¶ just one gesture, and the people of Bihar themselves will bury these traitors. This is not a fight of any political party ‚Äî it is a fight for the family‚Äôs honour, for the dignity of daughters, and for the self-respect of Bihar.‚ÄùThe controversy comes in the wake of Rohini Acharya‚Äôs social-media post on Sunday in which she alleged humiliation, abuse and expulsion from her parental home.She claimed she was ‚Äúdisgraced, abused, and even hit‚Äù after questioning the leadership over RJD‚Äôs poor performance in the Assembly elections.Rohini had named responsible for the family rift, claiming their actions prompted her decision to quit politics and leave her parents‚Äô home.
Article Summary: In a passionate outburst, Tej Pratap Yadav took aim at family members and RJD associates whom he branded as 'betrayers' for disrespecting his sister, Rohini Acharya. This vehement reaction came on the heels of Rohini's retirement from the political arena and ongoing family turmoil.

Article Title: Nithari murders without murderers: The Surinder Koli saga isn‚Äôt over
Article Text:

Nithari killing victim Rimpa Haldar's parents Doli Haldar and Anil Haldar showing victory signs after the special court pronounced death sentence for Moninder Singh Pandher and his servant Surinder Koli in Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh on February 14, 2009. (Times Content Image)

The Human Toll: A Ghost Killed Those Children?

A police bulldozer is used to uncover a drain to search for bodies, outside a house in Noida on the outskirts of New Delhi, on December 29, 2006. The police has arrested two men after recovering from a drain, parts of 15 skeletons of girls and boys behind an industrialist's house. The caretaker of the house Subhash alias Surendra reportedly told the cops he had been sexually abusing and strangulating his victims before disposing of their bodies in the drain. (Times Content Image)

The Culmination

The painful truths

Investigative systems can fail, especially when constrained by corruption, negligence, or lack of urgency.

Evidence matters, but how it's collected ‚Äî and whether due process is followed ‚Äî can make or break a case.

Confession is a double-edged sword: powerful, but only if obtained fairly and documented properly.

NOIDA/NEW DELHI: For years, the narrow lanes of Nithari whispered the same story: children vanished, one after another, swallowed by a darkness no one could name.Inside D-5, where life seemed ordinary from the outside, investigators later uncovered fragments of a nightmare scattered through drains, courtyards and rooms that refused to give up their truth.Two decades on, Nithari remains less a crime scene and more a wound ‚Äî a place where every unanswered question still walks the streets.The Nithari case remains one of country's most chilling and controversial serial-killing episodes. It centers around Bungalow D-5 in Nithari village, Noida and involves two men ‚Äî the homeowner, Moninder Singh Pandher and his domestic helper, Surinder Koli The macabre tale that unfolded over years involved skeletal remains in drains, allegations of rape, murder, necrophilia, and organ trading ‚Äî and a deeply flawed investigation that has haunted the judicial process for nearly two decades.The nightmare began in May 2006, when Nand Lal , father of a 22-year-old woman named Payal (also known as Deepika), reported her missing.Payal had visited Pandher‚Äôs bungalow D-5 in Sector 31, Nithari, allegedly to talk about a job for her brother ‚Äî but she never returned.It was later reported that Koli had called her from a public phone booth.Despite the serious nature of the disappearance, the police response was strikingly delayed.According to a former investigator (then sub-inspector, later DSP), no FIR was registered for months.It was only after a court application under Section 156(3) of the CrPC, filed by Nand Lal, that an FIR was formally lodged on October 7, 2006 ‚Äî nearly five months after Payal vanished.Things took a horrifying turn on December 29, 2006, when investigators discovered eight skeletal remains in a roadside drain next to the D-5 bungalow.This grim find, lead to the arrest of both Koli and Pandher. Within days, more bone fragments were unearthed in and around the drainage system.The discovery shook the nation and exposed the full extent of what had been a series of missing persons ‚Äî children and young women ‚Äî in and around Nithari.The initial investigation by the Uttar Pradesh Police came under criticism almost immediately. According to the first investigator, crucial delays had allowed the case to spiral: The FIR was filed only after months of pressure, and formal search operations began six months too late.These early lapses, he said, sowed the seeds of deeper problems.By January 10, 2007, due to mounting public outrage and the scale of the horror, the case was handed over to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI).Within days, CBI teams conducted intensive searches around the bungalow and adjoining areas, recovering more human remains ‚Äî skulls, bone pieces and dismembered body parts.The sheer scale of recovered remains made it difficult even for the investigators to determine how many victims there might have been.In the early months of the investigation, charge sheets were filed in 16 cases, spanning accusations of murder, rape, abduction, criminal conspiracy, destruction of evidence and more.On March 1, 2007, Koli made a highly detailed recorded confession.He reportedly admitted to murdering six children and one woman. He described luring them into the bungalow, strangling them, sexually abusing the bodies, dismembering them and discarding the remains in drains.He also made claims of cannibalism, stating that he sometimes cooked and ate flesh from the victims.The case proceeded in a special CBI court in Ghaziabad, and on February 13, 2009, both Koli and Pandher were sentenced to death in the first case.The trial court would go on to deliver verdicts over many years, across multiple hearings, more than 2,000 hearings were held during this prolonged trial.Koli was eventually convicted in 13 cases by the trial court and awarded death sentences in all, though one of these was commuted to life imprisonment.In a later case (May 2022), a special CBI court awarded him another death sentence for the rape and murder of a woman.While the trial court‚Äôs judgments were gruesome and seemed to close the case, the story was far from over.On September 11, 2009, the Allahabad high court delivered a big verdict: While upholding Koli‚Äôs death sentence, it acquitted Pandher in at least one prominent case, citing ‚Äúno evidence‚Äù against him.Over time, Koli‚Äôs legal team mounted a fierce appeal. On October 16, 2023, in a landmark decision, the Allahabad high court acquitted Koli in 12 of the death-sentence cases and Pandher in two, overturning the trial court‚Äôs verdicts.The court did not mince words: It stated that the investigation had been botched up and that ‚Äúbasic norms of collecting evidence were brazenly violated.‚ÄùA particularly scathing point in the high court‚Äôs judgment was the failure to probe possible organ trade ‚Äî an angle raised by a high-level committee from the Ministry of Women and Child Development.Investigators, the court said, ‚Äúopted for the easy course‚Äù by pinning blame on Koli and demonising him, instead of exploring deeper and more alarming conspiracies.The court also questioned the credibility of Koli‚Äôs confession. It noted procedural irregularities: the confession was allegedly recorded 60 days into police remand, yet there was no medical examination or independent witness.Moreover, the court highlighted contradictions in prosecution testimony about where and when the confession was made.Recovery of skeletal remains, according to the court, came from a drain outside the boundaries of Pandher‚Äôs house ‚Äî not from inside, as had often been claimed.Ultimately, the court declared that the guilt of Koli and Pandher had not been proved beyond reasonable doubt, particularly because the case rested largely on circumstantial evidence.The judgment drew sharp criticism from victim families, who saw it as a deep betrayal after nearly two decades of pursuing justice.Following the high court‚Äôs 2023 acquittal, Moninder Singh Pandher was released from Luksar Jail on October 20, 2023, after spending 14 years behind bars.Surinder Koli, meanwhile, was not immediately freed ‚Äî he continued to serve a life sentence in a separate conviction.But his legal fight was not over.In July 2025, the Supreme Court upheld the Allahabad HC‚Äôs acquittal of Koli in the 12 previously overturned cases. The apex court ruled that police lapses had rendered crucial evidence inadmissible.Then, on November 11, 2025, in a decisive moment, the Supreme Court accepted Koli‚Äôs curative plea (his last judicial recourse), acquitted him in the final pending case (Rimpa Haldar case) and ordered his immediate release.The man once dubbed the ‚ÄúNithari killer‚Äù has now been acquitted in all major Nithari murder cases.When word of his acquittal reached his barrack, Koli had remained seated for some time, staring at the floor. Then a faint smile crossed his face. ‚ÄúHe was relaxed, and there was a smile on his face,‚Äù a senior jail official told TOI.While Koli did give a detailed confession, the courts later scrutinised the conditions of its recording, It came long into police custody, without independent witnesses, and with no medical examination ‚Äî casting shadows on its voluntariness and authenticity.Perhaps most damning was the court‚Äôs assertion that organ trade ‚Äì a horrifying, but plausible, motive ‚Äì was not properly probed.The investigation, according to the HC, seemed to choose the less difficult path of blaming a single man rather than confronting possible organised crime.One sacked officer, Simranjeet Kaur was arrested by the CBI in 2007 for allegedly framing false records to protect Pandher and Koli, having received payments.The mysterious death of a key witness, Jatin Sarkar, whose daughter was among the missing. His body was later found in a pond in Bengal.Parents of missing children watched as time passed with no clear answers. The high court‚Äôs 2023 acquittals were met with ‚Äúdejection‚Äù by many, signaling that legal closure did not equal emotional closure.The community around Nithari, once traumatised by the gruesome revelations, still remembers the D-5 bungalow as a somber landmark.The Supreme Court‚Äôs acquittal in the 13th, and final, case against Koli left the families devastated.A 63-year-old Jhabbu Lal and his wife Sunita (60) continued seeking justice for their daughter Jyoti ‚Äî one of the children who went missing in 2006 and was later found among the Nithari victims.‚ÄúI had six children, and the fifth was Jyoti. She went missing in 2006,‚Äù Lal recalled, his voice shaking. ‚ÄúHer body was later found in the drain outside house number D5 (Moninder Pandher's bungalow where Koli worked).‚ÄùLal spent decades fighting in courts, selling valuables and even a house in Sangam Vihar, Delhi, to fund the case.Lal said, ‚ÄúIf he didn‚Äôt commit the crime, then who did? If he is freed, that means someone else killed our children. Why was Koli kept behind bars for so many years?‚ÄùSunita Lal added, ‚ÄúEven after all these years, the pain hasn‚Äôt faded. Every time I pass that bungalow, it feels like I‚Äôm standing at the same place where my world ended. We never got our child back ‚Äî only the memories and a lifetime of waiting for justice.‚ÄùAnother mother of a deceased said "Moninder (Moninder Singh Pandher) and Surinder Koli, killed so many children. But the case is not being done anything about. Who is guilty now? Was there a ghost in that house which killed all children? They used to kill children and indulge in organ trafficking. Now they say that they are innocent. Law is letting them go; God won't."When the Supreme Court finally granted his curative petition in November 2025 and ordered his immediate release, it marked the end of a long, fraught journey.The ruling underscored deep flaws in the original investigation: procedural lapses, contested confessions and weak evidence.Moninder Pandher, too, walked free earlier when the high court acquitted him.It was noted that during his release in October 2023, Pandher was frail, battling health issues including tuberculosis.The bungalow D-5, once infamous, now lies overgrown and decaying ‚Äî a ghostly testament to the violence that took place there.Even when courts finally render a verdict, emotional justice may remain elusive for victims and their families.The Nithari killings case, is more than a crime story; it is a mirror to systemic failures, a cautionary tale about investigative hubris, and a study in how the quest for justice can stretch over decades.The courtroom battles ‚Äî convictions, acquittals and final release ‚Äî have reshaped public memory of D-5 bungalow.But the wounds remain: for the families who lost children, for a village scarred by horror, and for a nation forced to reckon with how easily its systems can be outpaced by darkness.
Article Summary: Nithari case remains one of country's most chilling and controversial serial- killing episodes. It centers around Bungalow D-5 in Nithari village, Noida and involves two men ‚Äî the homeowner, Moninder Singh Pandher and his domestic helper, Surinder Koli. The macabre tale that unfolded over years involved skeletal remains in drains, allegations of rape, murder, necrophilia, and organ trading.

Article Title: Lalu pari-war: After Rohini, 3 more daughters walk out of Patna home
Article Text:

"I have no family..." Rohini Acharya Cuts Ties With Lalu Clan, Exits Politics Post-RJD Defeat

PATNA/NEW DELHI: RJD patriarch Lalu Prasad's daughter Rohini Acharya's outburst at her brother Tejashwi Yadav and his close associates for "abusing" and "throwing" her out of home is snowballing into a full-blown family feud and hints at increasing internal rumblings over the decisions of the party's anointed heir after its bid for office unravelled spectacularly in the assembly polls.As she dropped another bombshell on Sunday by saying she was dissed for donating her "dirty kidney" to Lalu and was accused of extracting crores of rupees and a Lok Sabha ticket, three of her sisters - Ragini, Chanda and Rajlakshmi - left their parents' Patna residence.Their brother Tej Pratap Yadav, disowned by his father and ousted from the party last year, spoke up against Rohini's "humiliation".Lalu, his younger son and political heir Tejashwi and other family members have maintained silence, an indication of the division and conflicted emotions within. The party too has kept mum.Some party leaders suggested that differences among the siblings have long been simmering as Tejashwi took firmer control of the party and leaned on a set of advisers loyal to him to run its affairs. That arrangement has come up for questioning.But the Bihar assembly poll debacle has opened up this style of functioning to questioning. Rohini said everybody is wondering what fate has befallen RJD, a party that governed Bihar between 1990 and 2005.Tej Pratap said in a social media post, "Yesterday's incident has shaken me. But the insult meted out to my sister is intolerable."I tolerated whatever happened to me but her humiliation cannot be tolerated under any condition... The consequence of this injustice will be very dire."He accused 'Jaichands' (betrayers), widely believed to be a reference to a couple of Tejashwi's close associates, including Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Yadav, of targeting the Yadav family. Appealing to Lalu, he said, "Just one nod, and the people of Bihar will bury these Jaichands themselves. This fight is not for any party; it is for the honour of the family, the dignity of the daughter, and the self-respect of Bihar."As the family fallout played out, TV footage showed three more daughters of Lalu's reaching Patna airport with their children to catch a flight, reportedly for Delhi. None of them spoke to the media. Incidentally, their departure came hours after Rohini advised women to "look after your in-laws and families and take care of your children" rather than parents."I would tell all married women never to do anything to save their parents, and if they have a brother, they should ask him to donate his own kidney or ask his Haryanavi friend to do so," she said in an emotional post. She said she had committed a blunder by not obtaining permission from her husband and in-laws and not thinking about the future of her three children before donating a kidney to her father.Earlier, she alleged she was humiliated and abused, and a slipper was lifted to hit her. She said her parents, Lalu and Rabri Devi, both former CMs, were crying and blamed Sanjay Yadav and Rameez Nemat Khan, who hails from Uttar Pradesh and is said to be Tejashwi's friend, for her "fate".She named her brother too but directed most of her anger at his two associates.The developments followed RJD's disastrous performance in the just-held assembly elections in Bihar, in which the party could win only 25 seats after contesting 143. Tejashwi was officially projected as MGB's chief ministerial candidate.Meanwhile, the JD(U) asked Lalu to explain the developments and act. "She is the daughter of entire Bihar, then why are you silent, Lalu ji... Please break your silence," JD(U) spokesperson Neeraj Kumar said.
Article Summary: Rohini Acharya's outburst at her brother Tejashwi Yadav is snowballing into a full-blown family feud. Three of her sisters - Ragini, Chanda and Rajlakshmi - left their parents' Patna residence. Tej Pratap Yadav, disowned by his father, spoke up against Rohini's "humiliation"

Article Title: Bihar results: RJD got more votes than BJP, JD(U) but fewer seats; here's why it happened
Article Text:
Tejashwi Yadav

‚ÄòMisa-Priyanka Ko Dickey Mein‚Ä¶‚Äô: Yashwant Deshmukh‚Äôs Message to RJD‚ÄìCong After NDA‚Äôs Bihar Win

High votes, low wins: The big contradiction



Contest more seats



NDA's math clicked, MGB's math cracked



JD(U)'s comeback flipped the story



BJP grows bigger than ever



MGB slipped because allies didn't deliver



Jan Suraaj and AIMIM changed the margins



So, what really happened?



NEW DELHI: Bihar's 2025 election results threw up a story full of surprises. Tejashwi Yadav 's RJD turned out to be the party with highest vote share in the state, yet it ended up with one of its lowest seat tallies ever. On the other hand, the NDA kept the power with landslide victory, clinching over 200 seats in 243-member assembly, keeping the Mahagathbandhan far from the seat of government.RJD recorded a vote share of around 23 per cent, just few decimals down from 2020, when it got 23.11 and emerged as the largest party with 75 seats. But this time, that same level of popularity translated into just 25 seats. So the striking question is: how can a party get the most votes, yet finish with so few seats?The answer lies in how votes were spread. RJD seems to have polled a large number of second-position votes. It remained popular, but not with enough concentrated support in winning zones.In simple terms, RJD got votes but not victories. This is no surprise in India's electoral mechanism of 'First Past the Post System.'RJD contested 143 seats this time, the highest among all parties across both the NDA and the Mahagathbandhan. In the 2020 assembly elections, the Lalu-led party had fielded one more candidate, contesting 144 seats.Contesting widely helped the party accumulate more total votes, contributing to the highest vote share. But losing candidates also add to vote share totals.Meanwhile, BJP and JD(U) fought on 101 seats each. They contested fewer seats but converted their votes efficiently into victories. That is why their seat count shot up, even with a lower vote share than RJD.A major turning point this election was the return of Chirag Paswan's LJP (Ram Vilas) to the NDA camp. In 2020, the LJP had hurt the NDA's chances by cutting into its votes, but this time its support helped strengthen the alliance instead of splitting it.In the previous election, LJP (RV) was unhappy with the NDA's seat-sharing formula in Bihar. Even though it was part of the alliance at the Centre, Chirag Paswan chose to go solo in the state and contested 134 seats, which ended up damaging NDA numbers‚Äîespecially Nitish Kumar 's JD(U).Similarly, Upendra Kushwaha's party contested 104 seats independently in 2020, further cutting into votes that could have benefitted the NDA.This time, with both LJP (RV) and Kushwaha‚Äôs RLM back in the NDA fold, the alliance appeared far more united, organised, and prepared. The result: NDA outperformed the Mahagathbandhan by a wide margin.One of the biggest turnarounds happened in seats where RJD and JD(U) were in direct fight.In 2020, RJD dominated these contests. But in 2025, JD(U) turned the tables and won 50 out of 59, almost wiping out RJD in head-to-head battles. JD(U)'s vote share also jumped from 15.39 percent in 2020 to 19.25 percent this time, helping it win 85 seats from the tally of 43 last time.RJD simply failed to see this drastic reversal coming.The BJP crossed 89 seats, its highest tally ever in Bihar, marking a historic leap for a party that once had almost no grassroots base or ideological legacy in the state. By staying aligned for years with "sushasan babu" and steadily expanding its footprint, the saffron party has now grown into Bihar's biggest political force.With this mandate, the BJP has effectively redrawn the political map of Bihar. It now sits at the centre of power, holding the strongest bargaining position in the alliance. For years, Nitish Kumar played the "big brother" to the BJP, but for the second election in a row, the BJP has outperformed the JD(U), this time doing so with its best-ever numbers.The shift isn't just about arithmetic -- it's psychological. For decades, Bihar's political story revolved around the Lalu‚ÄìNitish axis. Today, it revolves around the BJP‚Äôs weight, influence and negotiating power.Unlike NDA, the Mahagathbandhan struggled with coordination and clarity.Congress contested on 61 seats as compared to last time's 70, but won only six. The Left parties, which surprised everyone in 2020, could not repeat their performance either. Seat-sharing disagreements and confusing "friendly fights" meant votes did not transfer smoothly within the alliance.The opposition was visible but not united -- and unity decides tight contests.Prashant Kishor's much-talked about startup -- Jan Suraaj did not open its account, but it made a strategic dent, in at least 35 seats, its vote share was higher than the winning margin, influencing outcomes for both alliances.Meanwhile, AIMIM repeated its strong Seemanchal performance, winning five seats with 1.85 percent of votes and signalling a shift in political thinking among Muslim voters.The traditional Muslim‚ÄìYadav (MY) vote base of the RJD showed signs of fragmentation, with Muslim voters exploring alternative platforms in multiple constituencies, leading to a near wipeout of the Mahagathbandhan in Seemanchal, barring one Congress candidate who scraped through.Mayawati's BSP also registered a presence, securing 1.62% of the total vote share with one seat in the west.RJD did not lose popularity, but lost positional advantage. It remained a strong choice for many voters but could not cross the finishing line often enough. High vote share created the impression of strength, but seats reflect actual power -- and that is where NDA towered above everyone.
Article Summary: RJD recorded a vote share of around 23 per cent, just few decimals down from 2020. But this time, that same level of popularity translated into just 25 seats. RJD seems to have polled a large number of second-position votes. It remained popular, but not with enough concentrated support in winning zones.

Article Title: Bengal governor leads search for arms & ammunition at Raj Bhavan
Article Text: KOLKATA: Bengal governor C V Ananda Bose Monday led a team of security personnel and sniffer dogs in a "search operation" at Raj Bhavan following allegations by Trinamool MP Kalyan Banerjee "arms and ammunition were stacked within its premises". Banerjee dismissed the exercise as "child's play"."Governor Bose led the team of personnel, comprising Kolkata police officers and central forces, the bomb squad and dog squad, to find out whether there are arms and ammunition stacked inside," a Raj Bhavan official said. Bose, who was on a trip to north Bengal, cut that short to spearhead the operation, which started from the ground floor of Raj Bhavan around 2.15pm, an official said. "There was also deployment of personnel at Raj Bhavan Police Outpost. Officials of disaster management and civil defence departments also participated in the search," the official added.Raj Bhavan was evacuated and members of civil society and journalists were allowed to accompany Bose during the exercise, which was "live-streamed".Banerjee said: "...Why would anyone call police unless they have cleaned up the place? This is all child's play. He would not have to resort to such antics if he only followed the Constitution in letter and spirit... Actually, he has fallen in his appraisal sheet (among other governors) before the Union home minister. He is desperate to make amends. Let him complain against me in LS..."Earlier, after "nothing surfaced following the search", Bose threatened strong action against Banerjee as per legal provisions for his "baseless allegations".
Article Summary: Bengal governor C V Ananda Bose led a team of security personnel and sniffer dogs in a "search operation" at Raj Bhavan. The operation followed allegations by Trinamool MP Kalyan Banerjee "arms and ammunition were stacked within its premises" Bose was on a trip to north Bengal, but cut that short to spearhead the operation.

Article Title: Candace Owens lists 10 TPUSA verifiable lies and raises big questions about Charlie Kirk‚Äôs assassination story
Article Text:

She said the first lie was the story that Mikey McCoy had ‚Äúblood all over him.‚Äù She said this story was made up and was told by Pastor Rob McCoy.

The second lie, she said, came from Alex Clark and Andrew Kolvet. She said they pushed a story that Charlie Kirk was a ‚Äúcommitted evangelical‚Äù who only liked Catholic buildings. Candace Owens said this was not true.

The third lie was a strange story that Charlie Kirk‚Äôs ‚Äústrong bones‚Äù stopped a 30-06 bullet. She said Andrew Kolvet pushed this and that it made no sense.

The fourth lie, she said, was the claim that Charlie ‚Äúnever blinked‚Äù in his support for Israel. Candace Owens said this was not true.

For the fifth lie, she said TPUSA told people that Mikey McCoy first called his dad during the crisis. Owens said this story was also false.

The sixth lie was about Terryl Farnsworth, the AV worker. She said TPUSA claimed police told him to remove cameras. Candace Owens said her video review shows this did not happen.

The seventh lie was the claim that Farnsworth moved SD cards because ‚Äúpeople were stealing them.‚Äù She said this made no sense because SD cards are cheap and cameras are expensive.

The eighth lie came from Alex Clark, who said there was ‚Äúno bad blood‚Äù between Ben Shapiro and Charlie Kirk. Owens said that was ‚Äúpropaganda.‚Äù

The ninth lie was that TPUSA‚Äôs yearly audits proved nothing odd. Candace Owens said this was misleading because Doge worked differently from normal TPUSA work.

The tenth lie was calling Mikey McCoy a ‚Äúhero.‚Äù Candace Owens said this was not fair because he did not call 911 right away.





Candace Owens spoke on her podcast on November 13, 2025. She said she found ten ‚Äúverifiable lies‚Äù that she believes Turning Point USA (TPUSA) told after Charlie Kirk was killed. Charlie Kirk was shot in the neck on September 10, 2025, at Utah Valley University in Orem, Utah. The next day, 22-year-old Tyler James Robinson was arrested for the shooting.
